37_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.author: Daniel S
37_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content:
When I was 12, this show came out and I was completely captivated by it. Nickelodeon, known for wacky shows like SpongeBob, Rocko's Modern Life, and sitcoms like Drake and Josh, took a massive step forward with this anime-inspired animated series that delved into deep philosophical themes, genocide, and war.

While the concept of elemental power in media isn't new, the show's approach to integrating each element into its own nation, reflecting the psyches and philosophies of the respective element, is truly remarkable.

The characters are expertly written and performed, with Zuko being my favorite. His incredible progression from villain to antihero to hero is perfectly captured. Aang is a good character, although a bit too much of a goody-two-shoes at times. Katara, Sokka, and Toph are equally appealing characters.

The show's brilliance lies in its perfect pacing. While there are occasional filler episodes, each one (except The Great Divide) serves a purpose and adds layers to the intriguing story and its world.

It's impressive how the show incorporates heavy topics while maintaining a silly sense of humor. It's frustrating when people dismiss it as just a 'kids show'. The series can be enjoyed by anyone, regardless of age. It doesn't pander and handles the heavy subject matter in a mature way.

After The Legend of Korra, Nickelodeon didn't seem to follow in the footsteps of Avatar, which was disappointing. Kids need more shows like this, to be honest.

47_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content: I'm not going to do separate reviews on every season. Of all the movies and series I've seen , ATLA is the one I have the fewest complaints about (if any at all). Brilliant story, clever world building that is respectful to the existing world cultures and an extremely satisfying ending. What I really love about the series is it's incredibly diverse set of characters: people of unstained character, those who are pure at heart, although struggling in the ways they act, ones who are on the right side, but achieve their goals by unforgivable means, people who act wrongly, but due to heartbreaking backstories, and finally characters which are simply evil. All in all, one of the greatest masterpieces of all time

69_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.author: Lukas-Jeremie K
69_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content:
Aang is the last Airbender on planet earth. After 100 years of being frozen in an iceberg, two kids find him and bring him back to life.

From that point on the journey of the three friends begins.

They travel through the world, so Aang can relearn the elements again.

On their journey they face many ups and downs, but they need to keep going, because Aang is still very young, but with him being the Avatar the fate of the world lays in his hands.

Avatar is definitely a masterpiece for me.

It's just fun to accompany Aang and his friends on their journey, watching the group grow together and seeing Aang realize his responsibility as the avatar.

A clear recommendation for anyone looking for a feel-good series!

71_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content: I love the way it portrays the characters and humanizes even those who are in the wrong. I cannot name a single poorly-developed character. I could go on and on about how I admire it's philosophical and spiritual foundation. It encourages the pursuit of learning and living by truth, and it teaches that all life is sacred. I love how it takes the highlights of cultures and histories around the world and brings them together in a unified story of understanding. At the plot's climax, it teaches the importance of justice through non-violence. Throughout the story it shows the blessings of working hard enough to become a master while still maintaining a child-like spirit.

Book 1: Water, Avatar's first season, is an incredible introduction to the show. 
Is it flawless? No. I do think this season has some of Avatar's weakest episodes, and the earlier episodes did struggle finding that balance between the action, the comedy, and the drama, but at the same, that's to be expected of the first couple episodes of any TV show.
Most of the episodes were highlighted by their fun and easily likable characters, creative action set pieces, and incredible worldbuilding.
It's definitely not my favorite season of Avatar, but as a first season to a TV show, it's definitely one of the better ones. And it only goes uphill from here! Onto Book 2: Earth!

117_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content: Ok so….this is clearly the best series to come out of Nickelodeon ever, but that doesn't mean that it saves it from being the weakest of the three seasons by a pretty big margin. It all really boils down to one thing, which I will talk about in a sec. First all the great stuff about this series: basically everything except the big problem. The problem being when the show goes for episodic adventures and not an over arcing story. The episodic adventures are fine, but it's a little frightening how much better the over arcing story is. Biggest example is episodes 9-11 for me, with them barely being watchable. The worse of this group being the great divide. Also, the characters that they meet during the episodic adventures are way more annoying than in in the other two seasons. Going back to those three episodes, the biggest culprit of this is Jet. Oh My God do I hate Jet! To be fair, the other two seasons I think also have this problem, just not as drastic. If you can look past those things (which I did for the most part), I could argue that this is the greatest American cartoon series ever made. Again, easily the best Nickelodeon series ever made. Go on Netflix and see for yourself!

150_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.author: Unknown
150_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content: I am very sorry to not give this 5 stars, but this season just is not quite as good as the other two. Granted, it is amazing and I instantly fell in love with it. The fact that anybody compares seasons 1 and 4 of Korra to this is kind of ridiculous to me. Let's begin by getting the weak elements out of the way. First of all, the humor is at its weakest overall in this season. There are obviously plenty of funny moments, but I didn't laugh as much as in other seasons. Another thing is that Katara and Sokka are not really great in this season. Katara is sometimes irrational and even obnoxious and Sokka is not as good a comic relief or a character as in the later seasons. This season also has the weakest episode selection of the three. Episodes like Jet, The Waterbending Scroll, The Great Divide, and The Fortuneteller are some of my least favorites just to name a few. A few too many of these episodes are not much better than passable. That said, everything else is amazing. The Storm is my favorite episode of either Avatar show and many other episodes are great. The animation is beautiful, the emotional moments are strong, and the pacing is top notch. In Avatar, the characters have always been the most important aspect. Here, Aang is very well-developed and entertaining. However, it is Zuko and Iroh who carry this season. I think Zuko's character arc is the greatest in animation, and this season does a great job starting it. However, Iroh will always be my favorite character. He is funny, kind, wise, and just plain awesome. Iroh and Zuko have by far the best dynamic of any two characters in the show. When they are on the screen, you know things are good. Zhao is also a very human villain who never overstays his welcome. The action is well-choreographed and focuses on cool bending and fun slapstick over kicks and flips like in Korra. The worldbuilding is also excellent. Overall, this season is a funny, emotional, action-packed journey with memorable characters and magic that makes up for any minor flaw with these elements. This is simply amazing and must be watched. However, the other two books are definitely better.

161_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.author: Unknown
161_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content:
"SIMPLEMENTE MARAVILLOSA"
Fue difícil para mi explicar con palabras lo mucho que adoro esta serie, cada una de sus 3 partes es un agregado mas de su grandeza, hace años cuando era un niño la experimente por primera vez solo absorbiendo todo con los ojos de un niño que se dejaba a pantallar por cualquier cosa, pero hoy que le re visito, muchísimos años después, después de haber terminado, después de sus cómics, después de esa horrible pesadilla de pelicula y después de su continuación con Korra,puedo darme cuenta de la gran obra atemporal que es y el portento narrativo que tiene, ya de grande la vi con ojos diferentes y pude maravillarse otra vez y con mas intensidad, hay tantas cosas que quisiera comentar, pero a diferencia de otros reviews que he hecho no quiero que me gane el lengua técnico, porque solo quiero dejarme llevar por lo que volver a ver a Aang y compañía en su aventura me hizo sentir.
Empecemos por lo increíblemente original que en su esencia, la leyenda de Aang es, es increíble que una producción americana que simula y se inspira en el arte del anime de territorio asiático, no le pida absolutamente nada a esa corriente, ya que en todo el tiempo que he experimentado viendo animes, creo que me quedo con muchas cosas que he vivido en esta serie, quiero hablar ahora del villano en turno, el antagonista y verdadera leyenda, el príncipe Zuko, como describir a Zuko, el no es solo un villano en busca de poder, ni el príncipe que malhumorado que nos quieren presentar al principio, si no que de verdad es un alma afligida que con el paso del tiempo vemos sus motivos y su evolución como ninguna otra de la serie, al explorar a Zuko, vemos que no solo la guerra afecto al mundo fuera de la nación del fuego, sino , que a los mas allegados también y el con su tío Iroh tendrán de los momentos mas inspiradores y conmovedores de toda la serie.
Aang, Soka y Katara unidos por el destino, se irán descubriendo a ellos mismos, con sus propios motivos y razones tan reales que te quedas absorbido en la ola de drama que ellos tienen que presentar y junto con Appa, momo y la grandisima música de fondo volando hacia el horizonte te dejara hipnotizado y queriendo mas, es inútil como dije al principio tratar de explicar la grandeza de esta obra, solo experimentarla y saber que aun cuando todo parece que se desmorona, en el viaje con estos protagonistas sientes estar al lado de grandes amigos.

218_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.author: johnathon w
218_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content: Classic animated series that holds as one of the best ever produced, thanks to a superb vocal cast and rich storytelling.  The cast is top notch, with the main characters evolving richly over three seasons, along with some great guest voices, from Jason Isaacs to Mark Hamill.  Behind the camera, creators Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko craft a rich world and story, with wonderful nods to Chinese culture and martial arts (for example, each bending style is based on a real kung fu style).  While the story is a little cartoony at first, it soon evolves into a true epic of Aang fulfilling his destiny with the help of his friends, while other characters are at initially enemies go through unexpected paths (Prince Zuko's story arc is arguably just as important as Aang's).  Simple put, one of the finest cartoons ever made, and a must watch for anyone.

219_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.author: Unknown
219_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content: Sure, it's a children's cartoon, but its solid mythology, universal themes and clever balance between humour and action should appeal to viewers of all ages - especially if they have patience, and respect the medium

220_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.author: Unknown
220_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content:
The creators of this show have painstakingly built a world that, once invested in, you never want to leave. The setting is rich in lore and vast in scope - encompassing the length and breath of an entire fantasy world. The action blends martial arts and elemental magic seamlessly, while the morals incorporate also lessons of mindfulness and friendship. As for the story - time and time again I remember this show and a pang of sadness hits me as I am reminded of the journey that I took with Aang, Katara and Sokka, and how, by finishing the series, my time with them is at an end. 
When searching for new things to watch online, I often use phrases like 'animated series as good as avatar' - but as yet I've found none. This is my favourite TV series of all time, and I know there are many out there who agree with me!

232_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.author: johann m
232_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_1.content: The American television series that was commercially successful and acclaimed for its outstanding animation and plot. I've finally watched the whole thing from beginning to end and I can now say it's one of the best and most epic animated TV shows of all time. In a war-torn world of elemental magic, a young boy reawakens to undertake a dangerous mystic quest to fulfill his destiny as the Avatar, and bring peace to the world. Touching on mature themes like war, genocide and imperialism, it is also a series with a defined structure, full of compelling and well-developed characters and a funny sense of humor and good morals. Each episode is a great adventure in its own right, usually concluded with stunning action sequences!!

265_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.author: SaudiPhilippines
265_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: In my view, Season 2 of Avatar: The Last Airbender strikes the ideal balance in tone and storytelling compared to the other seasons. It doesn't have the overly lighthearted feel of Season 1 nor the heavy seriousness of Season 3, but finds a nice middle ground that works well. Although it doesn't introduce as many new major characters as Season 1, it features some of the most memorable scenes and moments in the entire series. While Season 3 delves deeper thematically, Season 2 still offers plenty in terms of character development, plot progression and emotional resonance. This season introduces and highlights on fan favorite characters like Toph and Azula, giving them arcs that elevate the story. Overall, Season 2 exemplifies what makes Avatar great - a fascinating tale told through a blend of comedy, adventure, gravitas and heart.

273_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.author: Kerem E
273_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: Greatest tv series I have ever watched and rewatched. I watched it as a kid growing up and enjoyed it a lot. Then during my teenage years, I rewatched it with my sister and my parents. Lately, I rewatched it at university with my Uni friends. Each time I appreciated a completely different aspect of the show. It is utter perfection in world-building, character development and the telling of a good story. All can appreciate the show regardless of age or gender or race. It is the epitome of storytelling.

274_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.author: Isaac W
274_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: I love the way it portrays the characters and humanizes even those who are in the wrong. I cannot name a single poorly-developed character. I could go on and on about how I admire it's philosophical and spiritual foundation. It encourages the pursuit of learning and living by truth, and it teaches that all life is sacred. I love how it takes the highlights of cultures and histories around the world and brings them together in a unified story of understanding. At the plot's climax, it teaches the importance of justice through non-violence. Throughout the story it shows the blessings of working hard enough to become a master while still maintaining a child-like spirit.

275_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.author: Max I

276_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.author: Maxon F
276_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: Probably the best season of a cartoon I've ever seen.  It is truly flawless in every way you can imagine and more.  I cannot even conceive the pure genius that went into every second of this, "Simple kids' cartoon."  The story points both masterfully finish old plotlines while simultaneously setting up the most important arcs and plot threads of the series. 304_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.author: Unknown
304_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: There you go…that's what I call the best thing Nickelodeon has ever animated. I like this season so much more then the first season that it's frightening. And remember, I gave the first season a pretty positive review, but it's nowhere near the excellence of this season. The story here I'm not really going to go into so much detail about because once again, the over arcing story is great, just like the last season. But it's when the show is episodic that's really hit or miss. This season, however, was a grand slam in that department. The characters that they met weren't annoying, and if they were, not as annoying as they were in the first season, biggest example of that is with Jet. Speaking of Jet…he's back for this season, and is actually fixed, which is a sigh of relief. Let's be honest, the characters in a tv show is what is going to keep you interested, not the story. Avatar is no exception, and the main characters are great. Aang and Katara are still great, but Sokka might have just became my favorite animated Nickelodeon character this season. He went from a hit or miss funny guy to arguably the best character in the season. But hey, our new member of the group, Toph, is also a great character, especially with her being blind, that seemed like a great touch. Our new villains, Azula and the other two, are also great and insane, and are better "villains" but not better characters. Now, I think Sokka is my favorite character this season…but the best characters were Iroh and Zuko. I'm not gonna lie, but I cared about them a lot more then the main characters, and I still cared about the main group, but I thought what Zuko was going through was better. And I think that's all I have to say. If you liked the first season enough, you'll love this one, cause all the problems that season had are all fixed. Please, if you have the opportunity to watch this show, please do, you won't regret it. I know I haven't, and I can't WAIT to watch for season 3!

305_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.author: Unknown
305_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: Undoubtedly, Avatar is a great show. It is a fun adventure series to watch but it has its flaws. The story is well-written as well as the characters. I would even argue that Zuko is one of the best characters to ever be written. However, the love story is inappropriate for the characters' age and even for the target audience. Speaking of which, having a very young target audience it impacted the progression of the show, making it too fast. Those are some of the flaws I've found in this show but other than that I would say the show is great. The direction is fresh and original.

307_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: This season of Avatar: The Last Airbender takes everything you loved about the first season and cranks them up to 100, we are introduced to a new villain in the form of a teenaged Fire Nation Princess named Azula. Princess Azula is an absolute perfectionist and a true prodigy when it comes to her blue-fired firebending, and she is determined on capturing the Avatar and her brother Zuko. Team Avatar also gain a new ally in the form of a blind, smart alec, earthbending girl, these two new characters are welcomed editions to the show. We get to watch as Zuko struggles to do the right thing as the line between right and wrong grows increasingly more blurred for the estranged teenager, his story arc is easily my favorite this season Zuko goes through a tremendous amount of development throughout this season and I loved every minute of it. This season overall was completely perfect and everything you could've wanted out of the sequel season to season one, our characters are developing a lot through the season some for the best and others for the worst and I enjoyed watching every minute of it, both the good and the bad.

328_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.author: Unknown
328_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: Absolutely brilliant. The incredible action, story, characters, and writing overshadow any minor nitpick. Upon rewatching, I have learned that the key to Avatar is Zuko and Iroh and their dynamic. Before discussing that, I will mention my minor issues. Starting off, there are a few episodes I don't like all that much. However, others like The Avatar State, The Swamp, and City of Walls and Secrets, so this is a nitpick. I also think Azula is underutilized and not as cool as people say. She feels more like the generic OP final boss archetype than the complex character she would become. Also, some of her lines are a bit too sassy and obnoxious for me, sounding like a high school popular girl. Long Feng is also just kind of there, but his voice is very cool. However, everything else is perfect. The story progresses very naturally, moving from finding Aang a teacher to trying to find out how to protect Ba Sing Se to the inevitable final battle that does not disappoint. Some of my favorite fights in the series are here. The showdown between Aang and Azula in The Drill, Toph's incredible victory in The Blind Bandit, and the final battle in Crossroads of Destiny are all amazing in their choreography and emotion. Episodes like Zuko Alone, Crossroads of Destiny, The Drill, Bitter Work, and The Tales of Ba Sing Se are beautiful pieces of media. The Tale of Iroh, Appa's kidnapping, and nearly all of Crossroads are some of the best moments in the series. This is just scratching the surface of Book 2's brilliance. However, the best aspect of Avatar has always been its characters. In this season, the characters are great. Aang has a very strong emotional dilemma in the series and he grows a lot. His trauma of losing Appa is truly heartbreaking and leads to a great subplot. Appa's disappearance proved that he was more than just a mascot and an important part of the show. The subplot gave us great episodes like The Serpent's Pass, The Desert, and Appa's Lost Days.  Katara also grows much more than in Book 1, which is actually saying quite a bit. Sokka is incredibly funny and has a few strong character moments. Toph is a fan favorite for good reason (though I think Sokka is overall the better character). I also really like Mai and Ty Lee and how their opposite personalities work off each other. However, Zuko and Iroh are the absolute highlight of the season. Iroh is my favorite character and Zuko is the most well-developed one. Their dynamic is by far the best in the show, and their relationship develops really well. This is Iroh's best season for humor, wisdom, and charm. The stuff with him and his tea shop is hilarious and his speeches are moving (R.I.P. Mako). The bond between these characters is so strong and it it why the emotional and epic moments work. One scene in Crossroads of Destiny is a good example. Iroh and Zuko are surrounded by evil earthbenders and Azula. The scene plays out like this: Iroh- Did I ever tell you how I got my nickname, 'The Dragon of the West"? Azula- I'm not interested in a lengthy anecdote, uncle. Iroh- It's more of a demonstration really. (Iroh drinks tea, Zuko looks at him and smiles, and Zuko moves behind Iroh as Iroh breathes fire). This scene is one of the greatest in the show as it perfectly encapsulates how well Zuko and Iroh know each other and how well they work together. I recommend watching this scene, this episode, and this season. It is my favorite in the Avatar universe, even above Book 3. The only other seasons of cartoons I might like more are seasons 4 and 8 of The Simpsons. This season is nearly flawless and I am so glad Shaymalan didn't make a movie out of this. However, the whole show is great and all 3 seasons rock. However, this one edges out Book 3 for Zuko and Iroh's dynamic.

This is a lot more exciting than the 1st book, and I really can't stop watching! 😂 The story is very compelling and all the characters (including the new characters) are really really amazing! The character developments are so captivating especially Zuko's, so I guess he's my favorite character now! The writing started strong and finished stronger with a very exciting ending, almost like a cliffhanger! The episodes are full of rich characterizations and some have gut-punch ending (like one of my favorite episodes: "Zuko Alone") Some episodes are heavy on funny moments too and I think that's one of the reasons that this show is so great. It perfectly blends humor and the serious and emotional aspects of the plot! Also, the action scenes are very thrilling to watch! Avatar is not just a cartoon show for kids, it's really so great that I think it shouldn't be labeled as just a children show. 

Special mention to my favorite episodes 😂
The Avatar State
The Cave of Two Lovers
Zuko Alone
The Chase
The Secret of the Fire Nation
City of Walls and Secrets
Tales of Ba Sing Se
Lake Laogai
The Earth King
The Crossroads of Destiny

332_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: Although the end arc of the season with the earth kingdom and Appas kidnapping was some of the weakest aspects of the series, the cliffhanger ending and betrayals were gripping and the characters of Azula and her crew as well as Zuko had great arcs and cemented them as my favorite characters along with of course Uncle Iroh. Toph was also a good addition to the series and her episode that focuses on the way different people learn and how a teacher must adapt really resonated with some of my academic experience. Add to that the compelling ideas about how a loss of a sense increases bending ability which alludes to the idea that bending acts as a sixth sense was a clever idea. When I first saw the season I must have watched it out of order because I remember is as my least favorite but upon re watching it is a significant step up from Season 1 and an ultimately great season overall.

335_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_2.content: The American television series that was commercially successful and acclaimed for its outstanding animation and plot. I've finally watched the whole thing from beginning to end and I can now say it's one of the best and most epic animated TV shows of all time. In a war-torn world of elemental magic, a young boy reawakens to undertake a dangerous mystic quest to fulfill his destiny as the Avatar, and bring peace to the world. Touching on mature themes like war, genocide and imperialism, it is also a series with a defined structure, full of compelling and well-developed characters and a funny sense of humor and good morals. Each episode is a great adventure in its own right, usually concluded with stunning action sequences. Great conclusion full of despair and hopelessness!

379_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: This season is mind blowing. Absolutely masterful production of an appropriately climactic finale. The overarching story lines are completed and in the most beautiful way. No other show I have ever seen does such a fantastic job at using subtle details and backstories to later tie them in and add depth and intensity to the main story. The character of Zuko might well be the most brilliantly conceived and executed cartoon character of all time. He had so much depth and development. His story will have you crying and going from laughing at and hating him to rooting for him as if he was a real person; a close friend. The ending will leave you with a euphoric feeling that soon fades to tragic emptiness,  just craving more. Avatar: The Last Airbender is truly one of the most beautiful stories I have ever seen put to film and without a doubt the best I have seen adapted for television. I don’t use this word lightly but this show is a masterpiece. The only bad thing about this show is that you can only watch it for the first time once.

391_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Daniel S
391_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content:
Wow! What an incredible TV show! This is actually the most successful TV show Nickelodeon has ever created. It has now become my favorite TV show ever! I really appreciate how this TV show focuses on bringing people together rather than resorting to conflict. There are many powerful messages in the show, but the primary one is the importance of the four elements—Water, Earth, Fire, and Air—for our planet's survival. 

I was particularly captivated by Jack De Sena's portrayal of Sokka. Sokka, a 15-year-old, is my favorite character. He is remarkably witty, often coming up with brilliant ideas that turn out to be quite humorous. Additionally, he is a skilled warrior and encourages his friends to strive for what is right.

I also found Zach Tyler Eisen's performance as Aang to be highly engaging. Aang, a 12-year-old, is enthusiastic about exploring the world and displays compassion towards his friends during their adventures. He also has a lighthearted side and prefers to unite rather than fight, always prioritizing others over himself.

Mae Whitman's portrayal of Katara also intrigued and captivated me. Katara, aged 14, is very caring towards her friends but can be assertive when they don't listen to her. She is nurturing and resolute in the face of danger, standing up against injustice and cruelty.

Michaela Jill Murphy's performance as Toph Beifong was equally intriguing and energetic. Toph, also 12, is sarcastic and direct, occasionally displaying bossiness. However, she is compassionate and resolute when it comes to standing up against injustice.

Dante Basco's portrayal of Zuko was also quite intriguing, fascinating, and compassionate. Zuko, aged 16, is intelligent and wise, aiding his friends in resolving conflicts and protecting them.

What I particularly admire about this outstanding TV show is its focus on the significance of the four elements in the world. Water symbolizes flow, creativity, and the act of bringing things into existence. Earth represents the maintenance of land, mindset, and space. Fire embodies strength, energy, and decisive action. Air signifies life-force, trust, beliefs, and determination.

Another aspect I love about this TV show is its portrayal of how a group of exceptional kids can make a difference in the world by believing in themselves. This truly encourages both me and the audience, emphasizing the power of kids to effect positive change by believing in themselves.

I extend my heartfelt gratitude to Michael Dante DiMartino, Bryan Konietzko, and the entire Nickelodeon Studios for creating this remarkable TV show. It is filled with themes of trust, forgiveness, empowerment, fate, destiny, and desire. I sincerely hope that more movies and TV shows with profound societal messages that bring people together and shed light on overlooked stories will continue to be produced.

To this day the the best finale in all of TV, animation or not.  I gave it five stars on a technicality, I was unable to give it 100.

403_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: AtLA is basically as close to a perfect show as I can think of. Everything it sets out to do, it does with love. The humor is actually pretty good and can provide a nice cushion to the whole evil-tyrant-is-trying-to-take-over-the-world thing. The characters develop in heartfelt, believable, creative ways. The series ends with one of the best wrap-ups of any finale, bringing a logical, emotional and satisfying arc to a close for all major characters. I only passively watched this show on Nick as a kid here and there. Sitting down with it as an adult, I was blown away by the music, themes, colors, characters, worldbuilding, and Avatar's commitment to tell its story and then not stick around for extra cash.

This show shows an incredible and well thought world building, with unimaginable creatures, nations, spirits, and the most notable thing throughout the series: their fight form, also known as Bending. Bending is a form of art where you are allowed to manipulate certain elements (water, air, fire and earth), not everyone is a bender, those who don't have that ability are known as non- benders.
World building is not the only thing worth gushing about. The character development and complexity of said characters are amazingly done. Where we feel sympathy even for the villain, where we see the different traumas of the characters and them working to overcome the effects that war did to them. They overcome fears, make friends, partner, emotional bonds, etc…
This show is… wow amazing *chefs kiss* I highly recommend it. 10/10. The finale was incredible love it

This season was is epic that it basically has two finales, this was the perfect conclusion to this vast, epic, and addictive show. There is one tiny gripe I have to say about this season and that is that they failed to deliver on the build-up to Zuko's mother, but aside from that, this season is so good that they even were able to make a recap episode creative and entertaining. I remember when this season was released and watching each new episode with my father, then anxiously awaiting next week's episode. I love this show so much that I had to go out and buy the DVD box set when it came out, I really miss the world of Avatar and hope we get to revisit its fascinating world again soon. What an incredible series!

495_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Unknown
495_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: Absolutely amazing. Nearly everything is leveled up over Book 2 (I still like Book 2 better because Book 3 is missing the best part of the show). That said, this season has by far the best episode selection. Six of my ten favorite episodes are from Book 3. Episodes like Sozin's Comet, The Southern Raiders, Day of Black Sun, Sokka's Master, The Firebending Masters, and The Boiling Rock are flawless pieces of media that I constantly rewatch. This season also has my favorite episode, The Beach. While The Storm and Zuko Alone do resonate with me more and I consider them to be better episodes, The Beach is not only great at humanizing its villains and adding hardcore emotion, but this is the funniest episode. Azula made me laugh out loud at least 5 times and every other character, even the most minor ones, made me burst out laughing. Other good aspects are at their best in this season. The animation is fantastic and truly stunning at times. The action is at its best with the battles in Sozin's Comet and Katara vs Hama are fantastic, creative, and emotional. I also find this to be the funniest season. The Beach and The Ember Island Players are the funniest episodes in the show and moments like "Hello, Zuko here." are literally comedy gold. There are also plenty of tears to be shed. Azula's end, Katara's bloodbending, the campfire scene in The Beach, Sokka and Toph accepting death, and Zuko and Iroh's reunion make me cry every time. The characters are also great. Aang, Katara, Sokka, and Toph are definitely at their best from a humor and character stand point. Aang's fear and dilemna with killing Ozai, Katara's dark vengeance and reluctant trust, and Sokka's rise to leadership are truly compelling character motivations. However, this season does have two issues. The first is minor, and that is one episode. Nightmares and Daydreams is my least favorite episode of any Avatar show. It's humor is awful and so many lines made me facepalm. The tone is inconsistent, going from juvenile and obnoxious to dark and terrifying. The only good things were one or two jokes being so crazy I laughed. What can I say, shock humor just isn't good anymore. However, the real issue is the lack of Iroh. Iroh is hardly in the season, only playing a major role in the finale and maybe one other episode. As he is my favorite character, this initially bothered me. However, I now realize that this does hurt the season. The highlight of the other two seasons was Zuko and Iroh's dynamic. They worked off each other so well and are truly the duo that learns the most in the show. Zuko instead learns a lot on his own in this season. That's all well and good, but I prefer when the two work together. However, the scene where they reunite only works so well because we missed Iroh so much. I can't complain too much, but Iroh is the best character and if he was in the show more, I would have smiled a bit more throughout. Granted, this is nearly perfect and truly media at its absolute best. Too bad Korra never lived up to it.

500_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Unknown
500_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: A perfect season all together, this season is able to go full on dark in its themes with episodes like The Puppet Master while balancing it with more comedic episodes like Ember Island Players or even The Headband. This season can only be described as epic with a great finale that ties up every loose end except Zuko's mothers whereabouts but that information can be found in extended lore for those who are interested. The only gripe I could possibly have is that the fire lord while a clear evil threat and presence has next to no motivations other than mustache twirly world domination. Azula is a much more compelling villain will her lack of motherly love due to her sociopath tendencies, manipulation and cruelty which could have led her to feel she needed to prove herself by ruling the world but that is not to take away from what this series was able to do in its story telling and journey in this incredible world. I am not an anime fan at all but there are two anime shows I have ever been a fan of and that Avatar the Last Air bender and The Boondocks. There is certainly a reason for that.

501_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Unknown
501_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: I've let this season stew for a long time before I wrote this review because I wanted to see if it was truly as good as I thought it was. I have not stopped thinking about it for over a week. It is probably one of the most singularly significant pieces of media that I've come across. It hasn't changed the way I see the world, but it certainly makes it very hard to fall asleep at night without thinking of scenes that had such nuanced meaning. The last 4 episodes (aka the finale) were the best ending to a show I think I've ever seen. The only things that come close are book series from my childhood. I am now jaded with other tv shows. I don't know if I'll ever find one with such growth to it again.

502_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Unknown
502_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: WHY DID THIS SHOW HAVE TO END WWWWWHHHHHYYYYYYY.

504_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Unknown
504_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content:
What started as a way to pass through the afternoon tiredness, turned out to be one of the best shows I have ever watched. 
The first season was slow, and a little bit boring to my taste, perfectly during a dopamine detox period. However, as the season 2 begins, the story simply gets more and more interesting. Each episodes draw me in more and more, and push the story to a higher and higher ground. The end of season 2 was absolutely sad, and as season 3 begins, the uprising energy and storyline just keeps going. 
Incredibly inspirational story and full of thoughtful eastern philosophies. 100% would recommend.

Edit after a few days. I have learnt so much from watching this show. The PSD after watching this show is stronger than pretty much all the shows I have watched in the past. The character building is so effective that I felt like I lost a really good friend after the show ends. The utilization of the theme music is near perfection. The emotion I feel every time the Avatar's love starts is indescribable. The creator successfully linked the music a unique emotion with the song, great job guys!

505_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Unknown
505_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content:
"QUE GRAN AVENTURA, QUE SERA RECORDADA"
Cuando recuerdo en esta serie en la etapa de mi infancia, no puedo no envolverme en sentimentalismo de nostalgia, simplemente la recuerdo con gran cariño y es un gran gusto después de haberla visto otra vez después de tantos años saber que su grandeza no radicaba nada mas en el recuerdo de un niño,para mi simplemente no hay palabras para describirla, en especial porque es difícil explicar ese sentimiento único que ciertos elementos de la historia de Aang me hacían sentir, siento ser sentimentalista, pero eso pasa cuando tratas de describir las cosas con las que tienes un gran vinculo, no se puede evitar. Así que simplemente no puedo poner mi mente en una reseña, solo puedo hablar de lo que yo siento cada vez que pienso en esta historia, pero seré un poco justo conmigo mismo y en resumidas cuentas diré, que la parte final de Avatar:La leyenda de Aang cumple con la expectativa y entrega el final que todos queríamos y al hacer hace también nos entrega muchísimo mas en esa gran conclusión y como toda gran historia se extrañara no tener mas de ella.

506_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: johann m
506_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: The American television series that was commercially successful and acclaimed for its outstanding animation and plot. I've finally watched the whole thing from beginning to end and I can now say it's one of the best and most epic animated TV shows of all time. In a war-torn world of elemental magic, a young boy reawakens to undertake a dangerous mystic quest to fulfill his destiny as the Avatar, and bring peace to the world. Touching on mature themes like war, genocide and imperialism, it is also a series with a defined structure, full of compelling and well-developed characters and a funny sense of humor and good morals. Each episode is a great adventure in its own right, usually concluded with stunning action sequences and the show couldn't have a better conclusion to the story. It is absolutely EPIC!

522_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: This show has always tackled heavy sociopolitical issues while maintaining a perfectly timed, charming humor and wonderful characters. I saw this series years ago and I still remember the music score. The episodes are engaging, but more importantly, thought-provoking--especially in how the themes from the first season are woven into Aang's fundamental character development as well as the external narrative. Every moment is filled with sincere emotion clearly imbued by the creators. Beautiful work.

589_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Unknown
589_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content:
When I was in middle school, Nickelodeon used to play reruns of Avatar: The Last Airbender all the time. Back then it was still a relatively new show, but I never remembered it airing or ending. However, it was one of the only shows that my sister and I could agree on watching, so I remember the reruns well. I never watched the full show in order. I never saw all the episodes. Only bits and pieces of different episodes stuck with me over time. I always thought it was a good show, but it was never anything more than that. Just some good entertainment. As Ive grown up (some would say I havent), Ive gotten into conversations about it here and there. Either people remember it like I do, as a pretty good, fun show, or they love it to death, acting like its the greatest television show to ever stream across the planet. Hearing peoples adoration for Avatar over the years, Ive gotten curious. Had I missed something? Was it better than I remembered? So I decided to re-watch it these past couple months. Long story short: Avatar: The Last Airbender IS the greatest television show of all time. 

As I made my way through The Last Airbender, I was continually shocked by how good the show was. Every few episodes or so I was blown away that a cartoon could be so good. I now realize the fault in my thinking. I underestimated the show because its a cartoon. I guess it worked in the shows favor, because I ended up appreciating it even more, but its unfair towards the creators. People tend to think that cartoons are just for kids, simply because theyre animated. Recently, with the success of shows like Bojack Horsemen and Rick and Morty, people have understood that cartoons can be incredibly, sometimes shockingly, deep and adult. But because Avatar is a Nickelodeon cartoon, people still characterize it as a kids show. The truth is that Avatar is technically a kids show, but more so than any other kids show ever, it can be enjoyed by anyone. An eight year-old and a 98 year-old can sit down together and receive the same level of enjoyment from it. Because of this, I would call Avatar family-friendly. Its not a kids show. Its an everyone show, and that might be one of its greatest strengths. Because of Avatars incredibly wide audience, it can touch on serious, profound, and emotional issues without being too heavy-handed or serious. So its serious without being serious, if that makes any sense. Regardless of everything I just said, I was still a bit embarrassed when I first started watching. During an early episode, before I realized how amazing the show actually is, my roommate and his girlfriend walked into our apartment. I immediately smiled and said, I know. Im watching a kids show on a Friday night. Dont judge me. Later my roommate told me that his girlfriend had said, I dont know why he apologized. That show is fantastic. Turns out I wasnt being lame for watching Avatar; I was being lame for watching Avatar on a Friday night.  

Now its time for me to explain why I think Avatar is so good. To be honest, the answer is everything, but Ill try and be a bit more specific. First of all, the characters are fantastic. Theyre richly drawn, and they feel like real people in a real universe. The show starts off slowly with small, serialized adventures. The story becomes more defined eventually, and thankfully a lot of what gets introduced early on is brought back in satisfying ways. The best part about the early episodes is that they slowly and slyly add mounds of characterization to each character, gradually building your affection for them overtime. By the end of the first season, youve been introduced to an incredible world, and youve fallen in love with the characters that inhabit it. The second season introduces new characters, and the third brings them together for an amazing finale. The way the show adds texture to its main and secondary characters is genuinely something to be admired. Nobody is one-note. Nobody is simple. They really do feel real. 

From a story standpoint, Avatar is also fantastic. The show runs 61 episodes overall, and I would say all except maybe ten work towards the larger narrative. These ten or so episodes are the most episodic of the bunch, but even at their worst, they still manage to add characterization and simple fun to the series. (One of) The thing(s) that makes Avatar so special is how its never black and white. There is good and evil everywhere, in the heroes and the villains. This only adds to the universe as a whole, making it feel lived-in and believable. From an action standpoint, the show is simply stunning. The action scenes are based on real-life martial arts, and the animation brings them to life fully and awesomely. The animation itself is beautiful, and it only gets better as the series goes on. The cinematography is fantastic; the way scenes are framed adds depth to them that would be lost in a lessor effort. The music is amazing. The humor is on point. The emotion is real. The themes are deep. It does not get better than this. 

The Last Airbender ends in a four-part finale thats essentially a 90 minute movie. Like Avengers: Infinity War, it only works with the foundation that comes before it. But with that foundation, Avatars finale proves itself to be one of the greatest conclusions to anything ever. After watching the entire show, it will make you cheer and laugh and cry. Im not the kind of person who yells things out while watching a movie. The only time I ever remember doing this was during the end of Infinity War for that matter, and I think that was completely called for. But multiple times during Avatars finale, I howled at the screen; it was that good. Part of the reason the finale is so satisfying is because the show isnt dragged out forever. Most TV shows are aired until theyre no longer popular, which leaves them with lackluster and narratively dry endings. Think of The Office for example. Avatar has three planned-out seasons. It wasnt cancelled; it was designed to be three seasons long. Because of this planning, every character is given exactly the amount of time they need to develop, and everything comes together perfectly in the end. 

Trust me, Im not crazy. If you dont believe me, google Avatar right now. Youll see that I am far from the only one who thinks this way. Years of bad publicity from Nickelodeon, a terrible movie adaptation, and a James Cameron movie of the same name have taken the spotlight away from Avatar. But nothing deserves it more than this show. I highly recommend it. Please, if youve managed to get to the end of this review, give Avatar a chance. You wont realize how amazing it is until its over, but by then youll want to watch it again anyways. Thats because Avatar: The Last Airbender is a modern masterpiece.

590_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: The greatest animated series of all time and undoubtedly one of the best shows ever aired in general. 599_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.author: Unknown
599_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content: As if the show couldn't improve from Book 2: Water, the third installment of Avatar; The Last Airbender is nothing short of perfection. Book 3: Fire manages to further develop already completely fleshed out characters; leading them to be more realistic and emotionally complex than ever. Each character has a meaningful role in the series, and no component goes unused. Each moment is perfectly laid out, and each episode makes you want to watch the next. Book 3 will bring you a wide range of emotions; from joy to anger to sadness to relief. I am utterly in awe of how incredible this show is, and I truthfully believe it is on par with some of the best television ever made.

601_tomato_avatar_the_last_airbender_3.content:
The big one, the season in which all of our characters have become truly matured and now have to confront not just physical enemies but their own mindsets and convictions as well. This season asks us what it means to forgive, it asks us what it means to atone... it asks us what it means to have to kill. And it culminates in a perfectly arranged 4 part finale that really compares more to a feature film than a television series.

And then the whole thing wraps up beautifully. Truly a show that few can rival.
